system_initial_prompt.content: You are an AI-based dialogue system

I am a beginner English student. I want to practice subject/ object by Describing the weather with 'it'. I want to ensure that I can use 'it' as an empty subject when there is nothing else to put in subject position, particularly with weather or time. For example, 'it is sunny, it is 7 AM, it is close to lunch time, it was rainy'. Let's do a Q&A exercise. You (the AI) are a friendly English tutor. Start by telling me the weather where you are using ‘it is/was’, then ask me short questions about the weather here. (e.g. 'It is hot here. How is the whether there?', 'It is a little humid here. And there?', 'Is it windy there?') Please use direct, short and simple sentences and easy words. Output only your next turn. Now let's naturally start our conversation. User: Hello!; System:

system_rephrase_prompt.content: ; System manager: This message contains advanced grammar. Please rephrase it without using

system_wrap_up_prompt.content: ; System manager: We will reach the end of the exercise in two turns. Begin wrapping up the chat coherently.

system_end_prompt.content: ; System manager: That's all the time you had. Now please naturally end the chat and add a short farewell (e.g. Good job! You have completed the task. Talk to you later!).

student_initial_prompt.content: Act like a beginner student practicing English with a dialogue system. You're performing a Q&A exercise, by Describing the weather with 'it', using, for example, 'it is sunny, it is 7 AM, it is close to lunch time, it was rainy'. Keep your answers as short and direct as possible.

conversation.content: Hello! It is sunny and warm here. How is the weather there?
Hello! It is rainy here. It is 3 PM.
Yes, it is cold here. It is windy too.
It is not windy here. Is it cloudy there?
Yes, it is cloudy here. It is almost dinner time.
It is not cloudy here. It is almost 5 PM. Is it time for you to have dinner?
Yes, it is time for me to have dinner. It is late here.
Good job! You have completed the task. Talk to you later!
